hackathon-description-text: HackIllinois is a 36 hour event where college students from across the country create technical projects ranging from websites and mobile apps to Wi-Fi connected microwaves. You can work on creating a useful tool that you wish existed or learning a new skill or language — anything goes!
hackathon-eligibility: University students of all skill levels are eligible to compete. We’re looking for a diverse mix of technical students from any major to create exciting, eclectic hacks. If you are an interested high school student, please fill out the application; we will contact you if there are any troubles.
hackathon-requirements: Teams’ demos will be judged on several criteria including usefulness, technical difficulty, polish, and creativity. More details about the judging process will be provided closer to the event. Teams will not be told their scores during or after judging, and decisions by the judges and HackIllinois team are final.
hackathon-rules:
All participants must be full-time or part-time University students during Spring 2015 except where permission is explicitly given. (We’re willing to work with high school students — contact us. ). Participation is closed to family members of judges. Upon participation in this event, it is implied that we reserve the right to share your resume and other application material with our corporate sponsors. By attending HackIllinois, you acknowledge that your picture and video may be used without compensation, prior permission, or notification in any promotional material related to HackIllinois.
 
For more rules, visit hackillinois.org/rules

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: The first place software team receives $1000, the second place team receives $750 and the third $500.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: HackIllinois Top Three Software Hacks

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How original is the idea? How creative of an approach do they take?
How well do they use technologies together? How complex is it?
How useful of a product is it? Is it something that you see people using in thier everyday lives?
Is it simple and straightforward? Or is it bulky and hard to understand?
For the final round, judges will be looking at all the previous criterion as well as how clean the product is - in terms of design, appearance, and sophistication?
For the final round, judges will be looking at all the previous criterion as well as how well the team presents the project?
